snippet: Rules proposed by the I.R.S. could leave millions of people in the lower middle class uninsured and frustrate the intent of Congress, which was to expand coverage.
abstract: Rules proposed by the Internal Revenue Service could leave millions of Americans unable to afford family health coverage offered by their employers and unqualified for subsidies provided by the Affordable Care Act; debate revolves around how to define 'affordable' under provisions of the law that are ambiguous.
lead_paragraph: Rules proposed by the I.R.S. could leave millions of people in the lower middle class uninsured and frustrate the intent of Congress, which was to expand coverage.

headline.seo: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly
headline.main: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly for Many
headline.print_headline: Ambiguity in Health Law Could Make Family Coverage Too Costly for Many

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
